results.title: Facing the music
results.creator_credit: Bob Connolly, Robin Anderson, Stefan Moore and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A compelling portrait of the struggle endured by Sydney University’s Music Department as it withstands ongoing funding cuts. At the centre of this portrait is Head of the Department, Professor Anne Boyd, a renowned composer in her own right, whose passion for music is matched by her staunch commitment to quality higher education. Boyd’s idealism is what makes her an inspiring, impassioned teacher in the classroom and a fierce defender of education at union meetings and strikes. Filmed over one academic year, “Facing the music” reveals in excruciating detail the sacrifices, emotional strain and tattered morale a university department must endure when faced with sustained cuts. “Facing the music” is made by Australia’s award-winning documentary duo, Bob Connolly and Robin Anderson, who, through capturing this real-life story, force us to consider the wider issue and debate of higher education within a context of economic rationalism. Should students fight for their right to quality education? Should Professors become entrepreneurs to ensure the survival of their academic departments? Should the arts suffer solely because it isn’t designed to sustain commerce and the marketplace? This is an extremely well-crafted, socially pertinent documentary that forces us to consider the role and worth of knowledge, research and the role of the artist in an increasingly hostile world of economic rationalism.

results.title: Dairying: space and system
results.creator_credit: James Coffey, Meg Stewart, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Geography”.
Questioning the viability of marginal dairy farming this film examines the various factors involved in assessing this industry as a spatial system. It argues the importance of the relationship of the dairy farm with the wider community at different levels, suggests changes which might benefit the industry and community as a whole and finally it asks how long marginal dairy farming can survive.
results.creator_credit_for_label: James Coffey, Meg Stewart, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia

results.title: Austinmere wheat and sheep farm
results.creator_credit: Edwin Moses, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Geography”.
Views the life, work, seasonal operations, problems and uncertain outlook of an integrated wheat and sheep farm in the central west of New South Wales. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Facing it: my friend's an alcoholic
results.creator_credit: William Haugse, George McQuilkin and Churchill Films
results.brief_description: Terry, 17, has a drinking and drug problem and his friend, A.J., is being drawn into it. A.J. at first covers for Terry, then tries to intervene. Finally he realises, with the assistance of Terry’s girlfriend, that they need outside help.

results.title: Facing facts
results.creator_credit: Barrie Smith, Peter Dimond and Supreme Sound Studios
results.brief_description: The death of a close friend affects Glen Turner so much that he reflects on how his own death would affect his family’s financial security. In a discussion with an Officer of a Trustee company he learns of the steps he can take to alleviate any hardship in the event of unexpected tragedy.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Barrie Smith, Peter Dimond and Supreme Sound Studios

results.title: Eye witness. No. 86. Bar mitzvah
results.creator_credit: Alvin Goldman, Peter Jones and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A careful portrayal of the ceremonies in which a Jewish youth confirms his faith. An honored estate, Bar Mitzvah - the coming of age - follows several years of study of the Hebrew language, scriptures and customs. Through the film we realize the seriousness with which boys prepare for the ritual that ushers them into the full obligations and privileges of their faith.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alvin Goldman, Peter Jones and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Fabric painting
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, Julia Wilson, Leigh Smith and TV Ed Productions
results.brief_description: Julia Wilson from the Correspondence School demonstrates the techniques involved in fabric painting on T-shirts. Outlines the types of paints available to use on various fabrics and suggests how to make colourful patterns.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jeff Spencer, Julia Wilson, Leigh Smith and TV Ed Productions

results.title: Fabric of a Dream: the Fletcher Jones Story
results.creator_credit: Dennis K. Smith, Bill Murphy, Melanie Coombs, Film Australia, Melodrama Pictures, SBS Independent and Neil Angwin
results.brief_description:
An inspiring man with bold and imaginative ideas, Fletcher Jones was influenced by Japanese reformer Toyohiko Kagawa, one of the most remarkable social activists of his time. Jones established his clothing design, retail and manufacturing business with an emphasis on quality, service and innovation. However, his primary concern was for people - both his customers and his workers - and they, in turn, were intensely loyal. This is a celebration of the man and his dream - of a model working environment based on values other than simple profit - set against the backdrop of 20th Century history.
[Source: NFSA Film Australia Collection National Interest Program]

results.title: Extensions of the family
results.creator_credit: Kathleen Shannon and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A self-selected “family of 13” buys a house in a large western city and shares responsibilities. Originally, four adults held the mortgage. Since the film was made, two of the original members have moved and new arrangements have been made to share equitably with other people who have joined the group. This is a continuing experiment with alternatives to the prevailing nuclear family.

results.title: Eyes, lies & illusions
results.brief_description:
An ACMI Screen Gallery Exhibition, held 2 November 2006 - 11 February 2007. See Exhibition activity record (ID 23) for more information.

Eyes, Lies & Illusions explores a pre-cinematic history in which art and entertainment, science and magic, technology and optical trickery are intertwined. The exhibition presents a dense ‘archaeology’ of the moving image, following ideas, devices and media from the Renaissance through to the present day.

Clear-cut divisions between the rational world of science and the playful realm of entertainment have never been easily achieved. New technologies possess the aura of magic. Art is given new, more spectacular expressions in the wake of scientific discovery.

Eyes, Lies & Illusions contains more than 500 historic objects, books, prints, instruments and optical ephemera drawn from the Werner Nekes Collection. This extraordinary collection began in the mid-sixties when Nekes, a German experimental filmmaker and professor, started collecting examples of optical phenomena as teaching aids.

The Nekes Collection has since grown to become one of the world’s most important and encyclopaedic private collections of pre-cinematic media, housing more than 20,000 objects.

The exhibition is interspersed with the works of 12 contemporary artists, each of whom is differently inspired by the imaginative power of visual illusion.

The show is split into seven key thematics: it begins with I Shadowplay, which leads on to II Tricks of the Light and III Riddles of Perspective. They in turn lead to IV Enhancing the Eye, V Deceiving the Mind and VI Persistence of Vision. The exhibition ends with VII Moving in Time, which explores the beginnings of motion pictures and cinema.

Eyes, Lies & Illusions works from the important premise that all media, at some point, were the latest scientific, artistic and technological inventions of their day. It reveals how no media, or indeed medium, is every truly forgotten.
